Key Arguments: Determining what constitutes 'misinformation' is subjective and varies from person to person.
No entity, including the government, should have the authority to decide what is true or false.
Historical examples exist where widely accepted ideas were later proven false, highlighting the need for free speech to discover truth.
The proposal is seen as a move towards authoritarianism, likened to actions of a totalitarian government.
Notable Quotes: No one has a monopoly on truth.
The idea that people sitting in an office somewhere in Canberra hold all the wisdom on whatâ€™s true and what is 'misinformation' is absurd - and deeply dangerous.
